deploy-guide/source/features/distributed.message: @Alan can we mention that cross AZ backups will break if you use "external". Can you give me some text for that?

In addition to not being able to have cross AZ backups, you won't have the cinder migrate offline feature where you move a volume (not just make a copy of it). 

Alan, is there any other feature they'd miss?
Done

Cross-AZ backups and offline volume migration are the ones I've identified, and confirmed they work when all sites use a common 'openstack' cephx key name (different keys, but same 'openstack' client name).

I'll offer more text for this section in another gerrit comment. I want to post my comments so far before I lose them.

Perhaps include something along these lines:

"Bear in mind that some cinder volume operations only work when sites are using a common 'openstack' cephx key name. Cross-AZ backups and offline volume migration are not supported when using a separate external cephx key."
Done

Add -e /usr/share/.../cinder-backup.yaml

You can pass the cinder-backup.yaml to enable this service on central so you can restore from dcn to central.
Done

Yes, and I would handle this with a note that's similar to what you added at L269. Maybe something along the lines of 

"Add '-e <blah>/cinder-backup.yaml' to deploy the cinder-backup service at the central site. The cinder-backup service running in the central site will be able to back up volumes located at DCN sites as long as all sites use the default 'openstack' cephx key name. DCN volumes cannot be backed up to the central site if the deployment uses a separate 'external' cephx key."

You only need to list THT parameters in the GlanceMultistoreConfig when their value doesn't match the THT parameter's default value. If the guide is prescribing the use of 'openstack' in all stacks then you can drop L472 entirely. You only need to list it at L480 because that's the situation where you _do_ need to override the default value.
Done
There is no cinder.conf CephClientUsername that needs to be set here. It seems cinder reads the [client] stanza of the ceph.conf.
Done

Well, not quite. Cinder's RBD backend _does_ use the CephClientUserName. Clients that wish to attach to a cinder volume will dynamically get the connection info (ceph cluster name and cephx client name) from cinder.

My comment simply clarifies your gerrit comment. The text in the patch looks OK, other than what I mentioned on L475.

Optionally, verify cross-AZ cider-backups work iff you didn't use the external key. You can back up today but you won't be able to restore until a future RFE is implemented.

 opnestack volume create to create volume x
 openstack volume restore --volume x

Hmm, this still troubles me. Assuming tripleo is correctly configuring the RBD stores in glance-api.conf, glance should be automatically using the rbd_store_user setting. Per [1], the [client]keyring value should be set only if the rbd_store_user is None.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/glance_store/src/branch/master/glance_store/_drivers/rbd.py#L100

I wonder if tripleo isn't correctly setting the rbd_store_user, or if glance isn't honoring the value and therefore relies on the [client]keyring value.

Please see http://paste.openstack.org/show/798244/

If this is considered a bug then let's open one but until that bug is resolved we should document that this is necessary so users don't hit the error above that I hit.

But compare this to L490, where you explicitly state (correctly) the CephClientUserName doesn't need to be set when it matches the default 'openstack' value. Explicitly setting will also work, but the reader may be confused to see it described both ways.
Done

As per http://paste.openstack.org/show/798244/

deployment/podman/podman-baremetal-ansib.message:
Are all of those tasks required for update? Is it worth changing this to implement only the required subset?

For example, I don't think the 'Ensure /var/lib/config-data context' is required.

So, it wasn't really required. But it didn't harm either...and I got two simple requirements from Sofer: "it must work and I don't want repetition" so this was the simplest way to achieve it :-D . I didn't know how to use yaml's * and & to leave that task out of the block.

You can either anchor the individual tasks, or you can move them into a block and anchor the block.

An individual task can be anchored and re-used like so:

- block:
  - &task1
    name: foo

  - name: bar

  - &task2
    name: baz

- block:
  - *task1
  - *task2

See this in the block/rescue in https://github.com/redhat-openstack/infrared/blob/master/infrared/common/roles/create_venv/tasks/main.yml

manifests/profile/base/memcached.pp.message: Is this patch still incomplete ? These specs are not actually passed to any configurations.
Hi Takashi, I need to pass them down to puppet-memcached. This is my first patch to puppet-tripleo and with puppet at all. Could you walk me through this part of passing the specs?

According to memcached documentations we should give the following options
to memcached
 - -Z
 - -o ssl_chain_cert=<cert file>
 - -o ssl_key=<key file>
 - -o ssl_verify_mode=<mode>

Puppet parameters (which belong to memcache class) are implemented here
 https://github.com/saz/puppet-memcached/blob/master/manifests/init.pp#L36-L40
and rendered into /etc/sysconfig/memcached by this template.
 

So what you should do is to remove "include memcache" and define the class
inclusion with explicit parameters, like;

  class { 'memcache':
    use_tls        : true,
    tls_chain_cert : $tls_chain_cert,
    ...
  }

But the problem is that these parameters are not properly rendered into config files in CentOS/Suse.
The following template file is used to generate /etc/sysconfig/memcached file but unfortunately it doesn't provide a way to set -Z option, while we might be able to use extended_opts parameter for the other options.
So I think we should fix puppet-memcached first to implement at least ability to add -Z flag according to use_tls.

https://github.com/saz/puppet-memcached/blob/master/templates/memcached_sysconfig.erb

I can help implementing these items, but I don't have neither very clear ideas nor test deployments for the configurations required for TLS-e. If you know any working configurations that would be helpful.

If I follow what you implemented in puppet-memcache, ssl_ca_cert is required when use_tls is true.

If ssl_ca_cert is optional then we should fix puppet-memcache so that it won't set ssl_ca_cert everytime when use_tles is true.

In addition, as I mentioned, puppet-memcache doesn't support /etc/sysconfig/memcached, so we still need to fix its templated file in puppet-memcache.
These 2 concerns are fixed in puppet-memcache 3.7.0.
Let's move this to the bottom, so that the order of parameters become consistent.

oslo_privsep/tests/test_daemon.py.message:
We have an issue with py27 here, with py38 the module socket.ssl return None for the original and for the un_monkey_patched attr so we don't fail here as None is equal to None, but with py27 we retrieved different method signatures for the ssl attr so this test fail.

Contexts examples:

With py38 `original_attr` is equal to `None` and `un_monkey_patched_attr` is equal to `None`. 

With py27 `original_attr` is equal to `<function ssl at 0x7f14cf3a96d0>` and `un_monkey_patched_attr` is equal to `<function ssl at 0x7f14ce2b2e50>`. in py27 ssl exist within the socket module [1] and not within py38 [2].

Either our unpatching doesn't work as expected with ssl and py27 or may we need to ignore some specific attributes with py27 in this test.

Always with the socket module, socketpair [3] and fromfd [4] are builtins with py27 and they are methods with py38.

I suppose the ssl issue is due to the fact that eventlet is based on PyOpenSSL [5][6] to manage SSL.

SSL is not our goal with this patch and we just want to unpatch things so I think we can ignore this module (exclude it from our tests), what do you think about this topic? 

Let's open a debate about this.

[1] https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/2.7/Lib/socket.py#L52,L84
[2] https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/3.8/Lib/socket.py
[3] https://docs.python.org/2.7/library/socket.html#socket.socketpair
[4] https://docs.python.org/2.7/library/socket.html#socket.fromfd
[5] https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/blob/af407c77f208ceefe5a35e39aed0cf3fdfc07cb9/eventlet/green/OpenSSL/SSL.py#L1,L2
[6] https://eventlet.net/doc/ssl.html#pyopenssl
As commented in IRC, I think we can maybe skip some library checks or create a list, per python version, of the libraries patched. That will truly check we are doing well here for py27.

One issue with making "vip" a boolean at the subnet level is that this would make it possible to set "vip: true" on multiple subnets, which is not a valid configuration.

I wonder if instead we should make "vip" a top-level string parameter (perhaps "vip_subnet" with a default of None). This way it is only possible to set the VIP on a single subnet.

Another option is to break this into two top-level parameters, "vip" (boolean) and "vip_subnet" (string).

Or we keep "vip" as a top-level boolean, but resolve the correct subnet automatically based on which subnet the API controller is placed on (which might get complicated).

Right, I was thinking we could validate it. Or even allow different services to be in different segments with their own vip etc.

Resolving the subnet automatically would be better, or even create the VIP only if a service that require a VIP on the network exist. I.e move VIP creation to the services config instead.

Let's just keep the 'vip' a boolean on the network level.

This model still supports only one IPv4 or IPv6 subnet per segment, but would add the option to have one of each per segment (leaf). I think this limitation is probably necessary to preserve backward-compatibility and reduce complexity. There have been some inquiries from users about whether it is possible to add additional subnets to an existing segment once all available IP addresses have been exhausted. I think the correct approach there is to add additional segments/leaves and additional roles, but we might want to explicitly call out this limitation and the reasons for it.

We could use a list?

We would still have the limitation on the ctlplane, and we would still need one role per subnet.

Using a list we could also drop the 'ipv6' prefixed/suffixed options?

releasenotes/notes/idrac-add-gpu-reporti.message: Wow, can we handle this in code? I'm not exactly a fan of merging this with adding an issue note sayign that incorrect results may be possible on 13th generation hardware.

This is under investigation, whether it is because of device configuration, or is the Tesla T4 GPU actually not supported on 13G. Idea was to go ahead with the servers that support this GPU for sure, and after investigating the case for 13G, do a bug fix (if needed) in the code and /or documentation.

When exactly does this error occur? requests is a mandatory module, according to cloudbase-init's requirements.txt file. You can't really have cloudbase-init "installed" without it, unless you patch it in yourself, or change your env's libraries, which is a bit concerning.
This patch is meant for using cloudbase-init without the requests module (for example, it is feasable to use nocloud metadata service without the requests module).

.zuul.yaml.message:
I see two jobs here, but only one is used.

It seems like we should have one job -- the one we use, and it should just be called "zuul-client-functional".

What does running the zuul unit tests test?  Zuul doesn't use the client, right?

It seems like what we want is a functional test suite in either zuul-client or zuul which uses Zuul.  I think https://review.opendev.org/752039 is that, right?

If so, it looks like once that actually lands, then running the Zuul test suite would exercise this.

The end goal then should be a job called "zuul-client-functional" which runs a tox environment defined in the zuul repo which runs only the tests in the test_zuulclient.py file.

Given that the tox env and the tests are defined in the Zuul repo, why not define the job there too?

When you update this change, can you update the commit message to explain the plan?  I had to do a lot of digging to try to infer what the plan was.  It's better to explain things to people in commit messages so we all know what's going on.

Here's how this was processed:

1. Plug cross-testing in zuul-client by creating the "zuulclient-functional" base test. At this time of the patch chain, since zuul isn't using zuul-client at all, this test doesn't validate anything and is therefore kept non-voting. 
2. Add zuul-client as a test dependency in zuul, and add testing invoking zuul-client (patch https://review.opendev.org/752039/ ). This lets us validate zuul-client against a "real" instance to compensate the shortcomings of mocking in unit tests. At this point, the zuul-client library is not used in zuul.
3. Make zuul-client a zuul dependency, so that duplicated code can be removed and imported from zuul-client (patch https://review.opendev.org/752039/ ) Because of the current broken zuul-client module in PyPI, there's a hack in the patch to prevent the tox install of zuul from failing. We need to tag zuul-client first then remove that hack before merging this change.
4. Fix last problems with zuul-client that were raised during the integration with zuul (patch https://review.opendev.org/751291/ )

It makes more sense to move step 1 after step 2, and make the job voting directly. 

 > The end goal then should be a job called "zuul-client-functional"
 > which runs a tox environment defined in the zuul repo which runs
 > only the tests in the test_zuulclient.py file.

Since all the zuul apps will depend on zuul-client (see https://review.opendev.org/752385/ ) it'd be wiser to run the full unit test suite?

 > Given that the tox env and the tests are defined in the Zuul repo,
 > why not define the job there too?

I've based this on what is done in the Nodepool repo, where the nodepool-zuul-functional job is defined. I'm ok with moving that to the zuul repo if it's better.

 > When you update this change, can you update the commit message to
 > explain the plan?  I had to do a lot of digging to try to infer
 > what the plan was.  It's better to explain things to people in
 > commit messages so we all know what's going on.

I will, I hope I clarified things.

ironic/drivers/modules/redfish/managemen.message:
So the default is 20 seconds. If we feel the need to be _that_ aggressive, then we need to likely try to somehow tune down the set of nodes returned from the DB.

Alternatively I think if we tuned the default to 30 seconds, that would reduce the spread. If we made it an even larger default say 45 may be better.

I guess with a thousand redfish machines, we're going to be hitting the DB quite a bit and iterating through a number of records, which may be quickly somewhat problematic if we're doing it too often.

Look at it this way. If someone has an average node record size of 4kB, and they have 1000 nodes, we're effectively asking for a database cursor and records to be returned of 4 Megabytes.

The reason why I made it 20 seconds is because the iDRAC deletes the Task object a fairly short period of time after the update completes - something less than 1 minute. As a result, if the polling interval is too big, when we go to check the Task object to determine if the upgrade was successful, the Task object is already gone and we can't determine success or failure.

I've written the code so that it emits a warning in this case, assumes the update was successful, and continues with the next update. Even with the 20 second polling interval, I have seen rare cases where the Task has been deleted when we go to check it.

I completely agree that 20 seconds is very aggressive. I also think that it's a bug that the Task is deleted so quickly. The Task should be available for a minimum of 2x the amount of time it took to do the firmware update. I'll file a bug with the firmware team on this.

I've increased the polling time to 60 seconds, since that is by far a more reasonable interval, though that means we will almost never be able to validate that the update was successful and just have to assume that it was (at least until the bug is fixed). The worst thing that will happen is that we will apply all of the updates, and whatever succeeds, succeeds and whatever doesn't, doesn't

Just wanted you to know there was a reason for this madness.

zuul/scheduler.py.message: What's the use case for an admin to set paused_on_start?

Afaik that's for the tests as long as the scheduler is not really cooperative so we can start multiple schedulers and run them in a controlled way one after the other (until they are cooperative we should keep them from loading the config at the same time). So I think that's needed for the followup change.
I could also imagine that in a multi-scheduler environment it may be useful to start scheduler in paused mode. But yes, the current main reason is for testing.
might be good to add a release note for the pause/resume command.

This can be simplified using the get_default utility function. You can see an example here: https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul/src/branch/master/zuul/executor/server.py#L2630

The type of the default defines the data type.
linters: F811 redefinition of unused 'TriggerEvent' from line 34

Would it make sense to replace the sleep and check with another threading.Event.wait()? Then the resume command can set that event?

Taking this idea further I wonder if we can use wake_event for handling pauses. I wouldn't worry about that in this change, but maybe something to think about as a follow on?
Sure, i like it. Looks even more clean to me.
I'm pretty sure I'm missing something -- I just don't see why that's the case.  Why doesn't it configure on start if it's paused?  If there's a line that says "if not paused", can you point me to it?
Why is this necessary?  How does the initial configuration normally happen?

The location is in tests/base.py:3627. The problem is that the extra condition in the tests/base.py if remove will trigger reconfiguration on start (even in paused state) and then in theory this condition is not needed.

But, at line 655 in here in the #reconfigure method the "event.wait()" will block when scheduler is started in paused mode. Therefore, if scheduler is started in paused state #reconfigure shall not be triggered before it is resumed. Then #reconfigure should be triggered when #resume is called in case no reconfiguration was triggered yet.
When the scheduler is started in paused mode it does not configure as the comment sais. That's why it is done explicitly here. Maybe I am missing something?

I understand the difference, but don't understand the policy change here.  Typically one would use double underscores if they wanted to protect a truly internal variable from access by an unfriendly subclass, or if they expected multiple subclasess to need the same variable name.  But I can't see that happening here, so I think we should stick with single underscores as we typically do.
Why the changes to double underscores?
I am trying to hide internal variables not to be exposed outside if i touch them anyway. Double underscore = private, single underscore = protected (exposed).

I was coming from the point: hide what you can and make it visible if needed. Since "protected" properties, methods are actually accessible as public, not only from a subclass. It also makes it bit easier to navigate the code when not as much things are visible. I would actually consider this "stopped" property to be truly internal variable. But sure, I can change that back.
Shouldn't the handler be pause no matter what is the status of the queue when `not self.is_resumed` is true?

Yes I can imagine such problem to actually happen. The pause/resume functionality is at this time meant for tests. We need to be able to control which scheduler is doing what. But I also see a practical use in production for maintenance or debug purposes.

Now, however, that case you describe may actually happen. Even worse. When I look at it: the event queues are still getting events in but are not processing them => queues are never empty => pausing is not happening.

We should make sure that a paused scheduler does not accept new events. But I am not sure how to solve it here. The event processing needs to introduce some locking/caching mechanism over zookeeper not to loose events. This is done later on. Maybe moving this change after all components are connected to zk.

We could also simply just pause no matter what as Tristan suggests for now.

I think the idea is to allow the scheduler to steady state with empty queues before pausing. However, I do wonder if that means a busy zuul would never properly pause? Might be something to evaluate as we start using the new feature?
This is the code that I think we can simplify (remove?) if we update the code in tests/base.py as suggested in my other comment.

is_resumed is cleared when we pause. But we try to wait for empty queues above before waiting on _resumed. I think that means we'll just cycle in this loop unless the queues are already empty when we pause. Rather than doing the nicer to cpu wait() call.

Should we drop this condition and let things flush before pausing? or drop the empty queues condition in the if above?

Perhaps another approach is to start with the much simpler implementation at https://review.opendev.org/588610 and modify from there if necessary? Note this change flushes the management queue then doesn't bother with the state of the other queues before pausing.

I was originally not aware of 588610, but as also discussions in IRC suggests, lets use that. We will definitely need queues to go thru zookeeper for multi-scheduler so that any can take an event. At that point I think it will make sense to wait for queues to be empty.

kuryr_kubernetes/controller/handlers/loa.message: umm, do we want to do this for every svc modification? (meaning one extra octavia API call), or should we go for reconciliation of all services/loadbalancer every X mins?

After releasing the listeners, only field which was left in the CRD was loadbalancer, but without the openstack loadbalancer, so it was tryingto create a new listener, pools, members, but the id of the loadbalancer in the crd is not find in the openstack, so if we check that we have the loadbalancer in the openstack, we can easily find out that something is missing and we do not have to patch just the empty {} because that is not possible because we fields in loadbalancer, members, listeners and pools are required, so when the loadbalancer is missing in the openstack, we recreate it, update the CRD and than everything can be recreated also.

yeah, I agree this should work perfectly fine. My only concern is the extra calls needed to Octavia API while most of the time the loadbalancer is going to be there. So I was wondering if we can perhaps execute this block only when we hit the problem of loadbalancer not being there (when creating the listeners for instance) or regularly executing this every, lets say, 5-10 mins, and allow the kuryr-controller to fail during that time due to missing loadbalancer

As the Custom Resource status is cleaned up upon NotFound of a load balancer resource[1], this wouldn't be needed anymore, right?

[1] https://github.com/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/master/kuryr_kubernetes/controller/drivers/lbaasv2.py#L712
